One of the most wholesome and wholehearted anime not geared towards children. 
PRO - Natsume Yuujinchou is a creative and beautiful show filled to the brim with colourful characters beaming with personality and all come with meaningful backstories. Understanding one another as a moral hasn't been executed so imaginitavely. This story is full of mysteries waiting to be answered in the next seasons and I'm excited to see them unfold and I'm also curious about whether or not this formula will last many seasons...
CON - But the ending felt off, like it was filler to tick us over. It felt like half of the seasonwas missing, which wouldn't be an issue if I was judging the entire show, but I'm critiquing this one and only season I have watched hitherto. The character development for Takashi is almost non-existant, we're introduced to him as a lonely and misunderstood character and while he does have friends he hasn't developed meaningful or deep relationships with them so far. Besides those nitpicks I still enjoyed the show and can't wait to get started on the next.

Natsume Yuujnichou is a great anime series which I absolutely adore wholeheartedly. All 13 episodes contain different stories which are linked together at some point. The way the plots are constructed is basically the same, yet it absolutely doesn't make them neither irksome nor boring. Every single episode should be highly appreciable, as the series concern important matters. It's not one of those profoundly sad stories or infantile ones. It's just remarkable. Composition is done greatly, the stories are very entertaining not mentioning the way the characters are developed. Only sometimes did I find anime series where equivalence between sadness and happiness is remained sosplendidly as it is here. That makes the series subtle and delicate. Instead of violence, it shows many aspects of being unique and how hard is to cope with it and keep it a secret. The subject of solitude is also presented very good. Natsume Yuujinchou bears with the issues very well, making the series one of the greatest in recent years. Actually, I dare to say it's probably one of the best ever. Despite the fact there are a lot of rather sad plots, it doesn't make the series depressing. It's more like the saying goes 'always look on the bright side of life'. And so the characters do. The anime resembles life with its ups and downs. That's the thing I probably like the most in it. It doesn't seem to be about some unrelated world. It's very convincing despite the supernatural features.



The main character inherits from his grandmother a book of friends, a nightmare for spirits. And that's basically what the series is all about. There's just one thing in common and the rest are accidental, sometimes even not related stories. Natsume has the capacity of seeing spirits which had brought him a lot of sorrow and troubles in the past. He doesn't exactly know why he can see them. They had been bothering him all his life, and he has no clue what they wanted from him. He desperately seeks other people who can see youkai. One day he sets free a noble spirit. They make a promise and since then, their friendship gradually become stronger, though no one will ever admit it. They eventually become inseparable and go through many hardships. Both characters are developed surprisingly good. At first, it's hard to find out what kind of relationship is between them, as they constantly beat or scold themselves. As the story goes further, Natsume finds himself being surrounded by many friends - humans as well as youkai and he doesn't feel lonely any more. He has to choose between youkai or people, as he helps both of them simultaneously, which is not an easy matter.

STORY 9/10


As the youkai appears only for each episode, every one of them leaves warm memories. Some of them appear every now and then, so we get to know them thoroughly. They are like people - some seek revenge, others are eager to befriend. For Natsume it doesn't matter if it is a human being or a youkai - he just wants to help them and tries to work out in which world he feels more poised. There are a lot of human characters who show up unexpectedly in various episodes. They are also very significant, because most of them carry important messages.

CHARACTERS 10/10


Needless to say, the music is wonderful. It gets along with the series, making it even more magical. As I like anime soundtracks, I can honestly say this one made a good impression on me. Openings' music as well as endings' is so catchy that it doesn't want to get away from my head. I don't mind it, but I feel a great desire to listen it over and over again.

MUSIC 7/10


To tell the truth, at first I didn't like the art in this anime. Particularly because it seemed to me too simple. I thought the youkai should be more detailed and the colours more powerful (fancy speaking, I started watching it backwards - from the second series ^^"). But then I realised that's the way it should be made and started admiring it ever since.

ART 9/10


I recommend it to anyone who wants to relax themselves. You definitely should see it, as it displays a warmth and cool affection.


OVERALL 9/10

Let’s imagine, if someone has an eye which can see things that others can’t, how he/she will feel? No-one will believe it and no-one can.
Natsume Yuujinchou is rather simple anime. In every episode, it has an individual story related to each kind of youkais written in Yuujinchou. It’s a small, and peaceful series that can be EASILY overlooked. NO. It’s filled with irreplaceable memories that you can’t forget.
There is no plot for this anime (or whatever.). Of course, it’s slice of life anime, and it has its advantages and disadvantages. It’s hard to keep the genre of ‘supernatural’ and ‘slice of life’ at once, butNatsume Yuujinchou covered that nicely. All episode are simply beautiful and breathtaking. 


Ah. Character development. This is what you expect when you watch this anime. Natsume is all alone boy who hates to interact with other people. He is gentle and kind. He tries to help EVERYONE. Well, you can call him hero in that aspect, but he actually thinks that he has no power at all. He keeps contradicting himself, about whether staying in human world, or being with Youkai like His grandmother Raiko did. 


In each story, Youkai tells Natsume about kindness, humanity and other lessons that he has been overlooked or forgot. His side kick cat always scolds him about how selfish and bad humans are. When he first met youkai in his new town, most of their responses are "don’t believe humans". But in the end, he finds out that not all humans are evil. Youkai themselves also realises and learns about their mistaken view towards humans. Very optimistic stories, right? However, it is not that cheerful anime. Its mood is somehow down from the start to the end. That kind of ambiguous tone is the one that makes this anime more intriguing to watch.


There are evil youkais of course. They are just evil. Same goes to human. Some youkais also struggles like human. This anime contrasts and compare those monsters and humans. We can see how Natsume's thinking changes through the whole series. He feels empathy toward those youkais. Most of them has been felt lonely or have been suffered from the problems of themselves. It's Natsume's job to cure those suffering youkais and tries to prove kindness of humans.


However, there is some problems with it, too. I sometimes got annoyed by Natsume's reflection about how he was lonely or get ignore. He seeks for similar people as him, but not trying to create a new relationship. That theme of 'loneliness' is something that has been used so much in other animes, especially in shonen. I mean, he lost his parents. Yet, he seems to feel nothing about it all the time. He never even mention it. They should have gave more background information about 'who exactly is Natsume'.


Art, probably one of my favourite character designing I’ve ever seen. Pastel style drawing and cute drawn youkais are just gorgeous. You can’t see anything like this in other anime. Very, very unique. Most of the background is consist of soft lines and colours, which creates very gentle atmosphere; contributing to the story. Sound aspect also reflects its atmosphere really well, though I’m not to sure about OP and ED.


Voices~~ well there is only 2 notable seiyuus here because… others just are just all recurring characters. Kamiya Hiroshi did surprisingly well with voice of Natsume, and you can sometimes here his usual ‘ZETSUBOU SHITA!’ style screaming. It’s fun indeed.


Overall value and enjoyment on this anime was higher than my expectation. Although it keeps with simple stories with simple plot settings, it manage to bring some beautiful development on characters and creation of overall atmosphere. It’s calm and peaceful. Nothing like Shonen stuffs packed with fight. So, this is definitely number one priority for those who just started animes.

“Loneliness cannot stand alone”
The Story...
It revolves between spirits and a person who can see them, Natsume Takashi. Natsume Takashi inherits the power to see youkai from his passed away grandmother, Natsume Reiko. As his life moves on he encounter various youkai that need his help and sometimes become a threat to his life.
The main attraction would be the tranquility of the story. It contains a calm and peaceful pace that keeps the story attractive. Even though the concept is quite simple they made it interesting by putting some minor arcs though out the whole series, minor arcs that also something to do with the mainarc.


The series also maintains the calmness on each episode even though they put drama and some puns to make it quite different, but in the end the calmness is still there as watchers will savor the meaning though out of it.


Art & Animation...


Beautiful, as it really contains as what you'll expect to this kind of genre. Scenery and backgrounds that gives a calm feeling, character design that is simple to fit to its surroundings, and animation that gives a big factor in making it as beautiful as possible, and also the one responsible for making it interesting to watch and gives emotions for every action on the show.


Sound…


OP and ED songs are great as it contains implication to its story. The voices of each characters are well delivered, the voices matches the attitudes of each characters which is kind of amusing. The background sounds/musics makes it even more charming thus it plays melodic, deep, calm, and soothing sounds and music for each theme of the story.


Character…


As for the main character of the story Natsume Takashi, he is a person with a warm-hearted towards youkai, a simple guy who lives in fear and been lonesome for quite a time. As time goes by he accepts being shun by human beings because of his special powers but even though he was treated like that he became friendly as possible to them. A good view about him is he possess kindness towards youkai and human beings that shows humility towards its purpose.


The advantage of the main character Natsume Takashi is he shows tranquility that greatly affects the outcome of the series but on the other hand it has disadvantage that might be the cause of the problem on the show, he is quite simple that has constant acts. Being simple is not that bad in a way that it will make a difference but in this series they didn't make some other scheme to improvise or make a difference on being repeated.


Madara is the other main character on the show that gives some amusement, he is a powerful youkai with some rude attitude, and also he become the guardian of Natsume Takashi for he will be protected towards some bad spirits. A good view about him is that he is too naughty in some ways that gives a grin in your face, always saying "stupid" whenever he have a chance to scold or make fun of Natsume.


As for the other characters, they fill up the series as intended to be part of it, they make a minor arc and appearance which also help maintain its calmness. Also being part of it helps the whole to revolve by making new friends and to explore the outside world that the main character doesn't encounter before.


Enjoyment…


It's kind of simple as it pertains simplicity in life, achieving that you haven't done before, courage to move forward, and being straightforward on every actions. With these kind of perspective you will enjoy it by its peaceful manner. 


Overall…


When you put all of these it will create a series that will surely hook you, but with these aspects it will surely be loved by those who wants an anime with peaceful appearance.

This story is very similar to xxxHolic, but it has a point of view that I feel is a bit more masculine.
The main character is a sensitive orphan boy who has always been socially isolated because he can see spirits -- and no one else believes in spirits.  
But when he begins looking through a book that had belonged to his grandmother, who could also see spirits, he begins to journey through the places his grandmother had visited, meeting spirits she had known, and sometimes finishing business that had been unresolved for generations.
There is some danger and fighting, but this is mostly a mellowstory that makes you want to convert to Shinto and spend your days communing with nature spirits.\n\n
I particularly like the way that the male lead is sensitive, vulnerable, and very much an underdog  -- and yet he is quite brave and willing to risk a lot of danger to face the unknown.  By contrast, the male lead in xxxHolic is a bit less aggressive and effective.

When sifting through a large amount of anime, you mostly find ones that are average and a little bit above average. They are the series that usually keep you entertained throughout, but with little more to be satisfied with. But sometimes, you occasionally stumble upon a series that is much, much more. With only 13 episodes to its name, I can say with sincerity that Natsume Yuujinchou is one of those series that i can definitely say is nothing short of a masterpiece. 
From what I've watched so far, I can distinguish that most 13 episode series are either average or poorly done, with somefew exceptions. Natsume Yuujinchou is an episodic series, meaning that it follows no straight plot but rather, tells one story per episode. Initially, you might think that because of this the plot will be rather loose and fragmented, but everything seems to intertwine nicely. 


The series follows the teenage protagonist, Natsume, in his journey towards understanding and helping the fellow Youkai and Ayakashi in his neighbourhood. What really shines is the interactions between him and the Youkai; they are so beautifully done that more often than not you'll find yourself tearing up a little as he passes through each of them. I guess part of the flaws of this anime is that the interactions are sometimes too short - the impact they give you makes you want to find out about them just a little bit more. Most of the episodes end with a bittersweet feeling that leaves you satisfied but melancholic. It's hard to describe, but it's kind of a sad but heartwarming effect. Each episode is relatively simple in terms of plot; in fact, the whole series is as simple as it can be. One could say that this is a flaw, but I say that it is a positive. It's just about an adolescent boy who, with his trusty cat companion, finds new ways to understand both humans and Youkai. 


One of the things I give the series credit for the most is the animation and the soundtrack. In terms of quality, Natsume Yuujinchou definitely doesn't shine in terms of crispness and it doesn't possess cutting edge graphics that can be compared to say, Guilty Crown. However, the animation of Natsume is very unique; everything is composed of pale, pastel and dreamy like qualities which accentuate the softness of the storyline and gives it that extra boost. The art blends together nicely with the interactions of the Youkai, and I found the scenery particularly pretty. That being said, I also loved the OP and the ED especially, simply because the art went so well with the rest of the series. 


The art also goes hand in hand with the soundtrack, which is composed of mostly slow, melodic tunes which really emphasize the raw nature of the series. I found the music really soothing in some parts, yet saddening in the scenes which ended up being bittersweet. The different components of the anime really flatter each other and, as a result, make it so much better as a series. 


For a 13 episodic series, Natsume Yuujinchou develops a surprising amount of depth and symbolic meanings as each episodes passes by. You get to see Natsume transition into a much better person through the interactions of Youkai; beings that he had disliked when he was younger. Throughout the series, I was expecting the whole thing to be a little disjointed or even a little fragmented in places, but I was pleasantly surprised with the result. I think that, by having a series with not much complexity in its plot means that it can be exploited into becoming a startlingly meaningful show by focusing efforts into developing the characters and everything else.

I'm halfway into Season 3 of Natsume Yuujinchou and I'm writing this review with mixed feelings and here's why...
1) Story Concept 6/10
Natsume Yuujinchou's storytelling style reminds me of Doraemon as in every episode is made up of mini story arcs surrounding the main characters. The story in itself is rhetoric. It can go on and on as long as the author doesn't run out of new youkai ideas. But while I enjoyed Doraemon very much without needing a story progression because the gadget surprises from his 4D pocket are more than enough to entertain me, I can't say the same for Natsume Yuujinchou. For thelatter, it gets mundane and you start to wonder, "So what are all these leading to...?"


2) Characters Development 5/10

I gave this an average rating not because I don't like the characters. In fact, all of them are likeable including most of the youkais. What disappoints me is the severe lack of character depth even in the main characters. After more than 30 episodes, I still don't know much about Natsume other than he's an orphan living with some relatives on his father's side. He has a pretty face, is kind-hearted and a wimp. Talking about being a wimp... I would think that Natsume would grow out of his fear of youkais after a few encounters especially with Nyanko-senei protecting him, but NOOOO. He still shrieks and runs at the sight of them, which puzzles me. Shouldn't he be used to them by now?? This again reminds me of Doraemon where the main character, Nobita, is forever a coward. But while I can understand Nobita being a child, Natsume isn't, so I expected some growth in courage. Basically his character doesn't change much other than he made some new friends (but not by his own accord). Even then, he holds these friends at arm's length. All in all, Natsume is a very bland character. 


My favourite character has to be Nyanko-sensei for he provides much comic relief. I cannot imagine this anime without him. In fact, I think Nyanko-sensei is the one who holds up the entire story. Even then, all I know about him is that his real form is a giant white wolf. Why was he sealed? By who? What was his relationship with Reiko? Not the slightest hint even after 30+ episodes. Is there a need to keep this such a big mystery? And I would have accepted any kind of lame backstory. 


The supporting cast are nice but really forgettable side characters. There're no backstories about them and they only appear when they're helping Natsume or just saying 'hi' to him in school. BLAND AS WATER. And did I mention that the youkais are starting to look the same?


3) Artwork 7/10

The art style is generally nice with good looking characters but visual effects are non-existence. Every exorcism scene looks similar. The way Natsume returns the names to the youkais are so simplistic it's not even visually entertaining. I would rather watch Sailormoon transform 100 times. 


------------------


Watching Natsume Yuujinchou is like drinking lemon honey water - a little sweet, a little sour, but not flavourful. I really hope that the story can develop more depth. I also feel that it will be nice to add a romantic interest for Natsume although the author had said that she does not want to focus on romance. But I feel that the romance doesn't have to be heavy and it may add more complexity to Natsume's character.


Overall rating is sadly only 6/10.

I was definitely late to the party when it came this anime that I heard so much about.  However, it had made it into my top favorites list.  This anime is so relaxing and a good slice of life with that supernatural feel, so if that's what you're looking for then definitely check it out.  Almost every episode made me laugh or tear up for bittersweet reasons. If you have more time on your hands, I definitely recommend to watch the other seasons as well.  This is one of the few anime where the other seasons still contains the feeling thatthe first season gave off.

Natsume Yuujinchou is a touching, thought-provoking and sweet anime. It leaves you with a warm, content feeling after each episode, and a wish for more of it when it's over (luckily there's some sequels :)).
Natsume, the protagonist, is one of the loveliest I've come across (although he does pack a mean punch when necessary). Natsume can see youkai, something most cannot, and due to this, in childhood, he was ostracised and shifted from house to house (a little something explored more in the anime). Despite these difficulties caused by his ability, Natsume continues to be kind and wants to help the youkai, and humans troubledby them, in anyway he can. He is the owner of the book of friends, a relic passed down to him from his grandmother who also shared his ability, which contains many youkai names which he sets out to return to their owners (in turn learning a bit about his grandmother's past along the way). 


The only other main character is Madara “Nyanko-sensei”; Natsume's catlike (literally) and somewhat begrudging guide/bodyguard to the youkai world. They do have a funny, yet caring relationship. Natsume's classmates also make a nice addition to the pack as recurring characters, one of them, Tanuma, a little more notable than the rest. As do Natsume's guardians, the lovely Fujiwara couple. There's a few youkai that make more than one appearance as well. 


The opening and ending themes are lovely to listen to, and also look great. The art and music coupled together, help to create a pleasant atmosphere in the anime. Some beautiful music and the art, and colours used, fit with the story very well. 


Overall, I highly recommend it. You'll experience a rollercoaster of emotions but it'll be worth it. I hope you enjoy the series as much I did. If you have watched, and liked, Mushishi you will probably like this. I hope you have a great day.

“So, you can see youkai huh?”
Natsume Yuujinchou follows Natsume, a high school student and his encounters with youkai. Youkai are basically ghosts, but not the kind you see in kids’ cartoons or horror movies – they are just funky looking monsters that are invisible to most humans. Once a youkai gives its name to a human, then it pledges its soul to the human and they can never truly pass on unless they have their names back. Natsume’s grandmother, Reiko, had collected the names of various youkai and recorded them in a book called the “Yuujinchou” or “The Book of Friends”. After her death, thisbook falls into Natsume’s hand, who decides to free any youkai from its contract by giving the youkai its name back upon request. However, while some youkai just want their name back, some want to have the entire Yuujinchou so that they can control the other youkai. Along with his bodyguard Madara, the demon cat, Natsume begins to return the youkai’s names, one by one…


Natsume Yuujinchou is a watered down cross between Mushishi, xxxHOLiC and Kino’s Journey. In each episode, Natsume encounters a youkai who has some unfinished business in this world and needs Natsume’s help to finish it, so that they can move on. However, this is easier said than done, as some of the youkai’s requests are unreasonable to say the least and could even result in Natsume’s death. The anime has its genres mixed in the right proportion, with a strong dose of “Fantasy”, a spoonful of “Action” and a dash of “Slice of Life”. Set in an episodic format, all these elements come together really well, and each episode tells a fascinating tale that is truly heartwarming. 


However, certain episodes felt like “filler” episodes, which is inexcusable in a 13 episode series, and contained an unduly high amount of slapstick comedy. And although the overall plot is pretty unique and is handled in a charming fashion, it is pretty predictable. Maybe it’s just me, but after watching Mushishi, Kino’s Journey and xxxHOLiC, NY seemed rather linear and somehow didn’t quite capture the mood like the anime above did. Another place where this show went wrong was by mixing in some shounen elements, which did not work out well – this anime should’ve strictly stuck to the seinen genre. 


The animation is perfect for this kind of series – soft, subtle and clean. Backgrounds were sharp and were beautiful to look at. The characters look pretty realistic and the eyes, thankfully, don’t occupy half of the character’s face. But, I felt that the youkai could’ve been drawn more artfully. When I picked this series up, I did not expect the youkai to look like the low grade demons in Inuyasha or the evil monsters from Gegege no Kitarou. Sadly, they did. Although it was not intolerable by any means, it was one of the reasons why I didn’t give this anime a ten or a nine. An overall solid job - Brains Base excels again!


The music was excellent. The OP was superb and the lyrics actually made sense, which is something you don’t see every day. The ED was a bit weird, with shaky vocals and a pleasant rhythm. The BGM was apt and fit the scenes perfectly. There were a few quirky tracks, a few melancholy ones and a few dramatic ones. And they all do a great job in setting the mood. 


The characters consisted mainly of Natsume and Madara. There are a couple of other characters, but they don’t have a lot of role to play. Natsume is your standard high school protagonist – shy, quiet and kind. He talks to himself; his parents are dead and he is shunned by the society because he can see youkai, while no one else can. And his very stereotypical portrayal is what gives this anime a shonen feel. I mean, the kid is just too easy to read. The one other character that you see in every episode is Madara, the demon cat. Madara offers to be Natume’s bodyguard and for payment for his services, he gets the Yuujinchou when Natsume dies. Madara is mainly intended for comic relief, but sometimes, he can just be boring, with the jokes becoming stale fast. And this silly humor relaxes the atmosphere and makes the mood less serious, which, in my opinion, is not a good addition at all, as shows like NY are meant to be charming, yet focused at the same time. 


The interaction between Natsume and Madara is extraordinarily similar to that of Kino and Hermes, certain youkai’s stories are extremely similar to that of xxxHOLiC’s and the Tanamu is just a replica of Adashino from Mushishi. And seeing that this anime was released in 2009, way after the release of all the above three anime, eyebrows are bound to be raised. Also, the boy seeing ghosts reminds me strongly of the Hollywood movie “The Sixth Sense”.


But, when it’s all said and done, NY is a great anime that succeeds mainly because of its focus on humans and not on the youkai. The youkai are just a medium to bring out the various kinds of bonds two humans can have. Once you get that into your head, NY will not disappoint. The first four episodes were somehow not as good as the rest of the series, but they were not terrible either. 


The voice acting was neatly done and the subs by BSS were awesome as always.


[THE WRAP-UP ]

Natsume Yuujinchou is a beautiful show. With a generous helping of genres such as comedy, slice of life and drama, this anime is proof that you don’t always need the guns, women or a prophecy, for telling an absorbing tale of a boy with superpowers. Charming animation breathes life into the series and the stellar soundtrack is perfect for this show. However, poor characters, boring comedy and inconsistency in the quality of the episodes pull down this episodic series’ score. Strong similarities to other shows of the same genre also make the viewers question the originality of the producers. But, even these glaring errors cannot prevent you from adoring this anime. Natsume Yuujinchou is definitely worth your time. If you’re unsatisfied after the first six episodes, then this series is probably not for you. However, the sequel, Zoku Natsume Yuujinchou, is far better than this season, so if you didn’t like this one, there’s a much better chance you’ll like the sequel. Natsume Yuujinchou is exactly what the MAL score of 8 means – a very good show. 


(As always, feedback of any form is welcome. Thank you for your time ^^ !)

Story – 7/10
Natsume Yuujinchou’s (NY) story is very light and charming. There is no over-arching plot with twists, though there are occasional flashbacks that help develop Reiko and Takashi’s character. The story mostly consists of light comedy, some sad situations, and many happy endings for each individual stand alone episode. Some episodes are better than others (that is to be expected), especially towards the last few episodes of the season. Therefore, the quality of the story varies for each episode. While this anime’s plot is not as heavy and emotionally engaging as other anime (ex. Fruits Basket), the story is quite charming and enjoyable.
Animation –8/10


The animation is for this show is very good. The human character drawings are consistently good, with very few instances where the quality is less than acceptable. In other words, the soft colors, human character designs, and their backgrounds complement the show’s charm. Further, the spirit design is wide and varied that separates each individual spirit from each other. Though there is a more noticeable drop in quality for the spirit drawings when compared to the humans.


Characters – 8/10


The main characters Natsume and “Nyanko-sensei” (Madara) are a funny couple to watch. Some of the characters turn out to be very likeable despite only seeing them for a few episodes (for example, the wolf boy), however some are rather one dimensional. Overall, the main and supporting cast of NY is characterized in a good manner.


Music – 9/10


If anything stands out for me in this series, it is the music. The ED of the show is rather slow and peaceful like the series itself; the singing and lyrics are full of emotion. The OP is good too, however the ED is more memorable because of its melodies. Overall, the soundtrack was excellent with emphasis on the ED.


Enjoyment  – 7/10


Overall, I felt that this anime did its job of delivering its charming and playful message to the audience. It may not have all the frills and thrills of other shows, however it’s a good anime to pick up if you are in the market for a light feel good show with a little bit of comedy.


Average Series Rating – 7.375/10

Natsume Yuujinchou is anime with unique atmosphere. While watching this series (especially first three seasons) you can feel some kind of "magic" flowing out of your screen. Depending on personality, many emotions can reach you. For sure, the biggest amount of emotions is being felt by melancholic. But this isn't the point. Everyone can see "Natsume Yuujinchou", but not every person would tolerate slowly plot and in consequence not every person would feel the full potential of this anime.
Story - 8/10
But let's slow down a bit. Basically, the plot line tells about a regular student living in common japanese village. His name is Natsume Takashiand what's important - his parents deceased. Because of that, he need to face the reality and people who simply treats him bad. The most important is his ability which allows him to see demons and ghosts called "youkai". Excluded between people, living between ghosts - this is main topic taken by creator. The spectator's job is to confirm the fact, that Natsume is doing well in his "little own world".


Art - 6/10


About the art: admittedly it's getting better and better with every season. It's not extra-special but also it's not worst. Gradually with watching, the viewer gets used to the art. The point is to survive until it happen. ; )


Sound - 6/10


It could be controversial for Natsume's fans, but in my opinion music used in whole series is it's weak point. To be precise: i mean OST inside anime, without openings and endings. On the other hand, every OP and ED matches this anime in 100%. The rest of sound is like art - it also matches, but it could be better. (if openings and enings matches in 100% then OST would match in 55%). 


Character - 8/10


When i look back on Natsume and his "pet" (yes, he have a "uniqe" cat), i remember the contrast between this main characters. We have a introvert and shy Natsume who "attack" the spectator with huge amount of emotions. But this attack is very, very subtle. In the other hand we have Madara or maybe Nyanko-sensei, who is expressive and direct. Except this two, we have Natsume's friends. Every of them have something that Natsume is missing. That makes us see the characters.as a "puzzle". Everyone is completing with each other - especlially with Natsume.


Enjoyment - 10/10


Let's forget about music and art and move to enjoyment. If you're into fights and blood, stop reading this. And don't watch Natsume Yuujichou. Really, it's for your sake. But! If you don't mind calm and light mix of drama and comedy, you'll feel all of possible enjoyment flowing out of this anime, like i felt. The Natsume adventures are exciting, even if they're monotonous. (I know, it sounds unbelievable, but it is truth XD)


*drums* Overall - 10/10


Don't get angry, shounen fans. Personally, I'm melancholic and calm like this anime is. And that's why I ended with rating it on 10 points.I'm almost sure that if you're even a bit like me, you'll like the Natsume series because of it's magic. But it's not only magic. It's both a striking realism (Natsume in society thread) and a thin veil of fiction whitch covers the real world. So, we have 8, 6, 6 ,8 and 10. But who cares about the average score from this numbers? Only final feelings matters, doesn't it? ; )

Natsume Yuujinchou is about the bonds and relationships we come across no matter how short or long they last. This series is beautiful for not only its’ characters and stories, but for the art and music as well.
It is not often that I can right out say what a favorite of mine is; for example movies,
bands, tv shows, actors, and so on. But if someone was to ask me what my favorite anime was, I’d immediately say, ‘Natsume Yuujinchou’.
This series as made me cry, laugh, and sigh with its’ story telling. Most of the episodes introduces a new youkai and their trouble. At first itis only the ones that have their names’ in Reiko’s old book of friends, but as the series goes on ones that Natsume just happens to come across and meet show up. 9 out of 10 times they cause trouble, but most of the time their intent is not malicious.


The one episode stories can be so heartbreaking, and there is struggle and pain that has to be faced. Yet there is a resolution that comes at the end, not always as Natsume hoped it would be, but there is always a sense of peace at the end; even in the sadness.


Later in the series Natsume meets some humans that he can relate too. Though isn’t as he hoped it would be, there is regret in the joy. Again his interactions help him grow and shape into a stronger and surer character.


Natsume is an excellent lead; there is a sad history that is easy to sympathize with, yet he doesn’t live by that history. He’s very much a present and future focused type of character; keeping him from being whiny and annoying. He also is a very empathetic and kind person that always wants to help; even it means risking his life (something that really annoys Nyanko-sensei). It’s very hard not to like him; at least a little.


Nyanko-sensei is the teacher and main source of humor for the series. He is the relief from overload of tension. Some might find him annoying at first, until it becomes clear that he’s growing attached to Natsume; no matter how much he might deny it. There is a heart under all the fat and selfishness.


Together it is heaven, opposites in some ways and kindred souls in others. Their ever evolving relationship is what shapes the core of this series. One of the best none romantic partnerships out there for anime and manga, even if in season one it is new and just starting to develop.


Overall the characters are the heart and soul of Natsume Yuujinchou. Their history and outlook on life makes it easy to connect and feel for them. Sometimes their stay is very brief and others they just happen to reappear (sometimes much to Natsume’s chagrin) giving a familiar face to see once in a while.


Of course the characters wouldn’t so memorable if it wasn’t for the people giving them voices. The talent is mind boggling it is so impressive. It is hard to imagine anyone but Kamiya Hiroshi as Natsume what with his gentle and smooth voice being the narration. Or Inoue Kazuhiko as Nyanko-sensei; he is good at being hilarious and serious at the same time, still have no clue how he does that. The rest of the cast is just as good, but not as important (lead wise). If you watch a lot of recent anime you’ll recognize a bundle of seiyu or voices.


I’m going to combine the music and art together, because they complement each other so well. That and when I hear the soundtrack I think of the art or vice versa. The art is soft and full of pastels. The sky is full of fluffy clouds and the backgrounds draw you in and make you feel like you really could be in Japan’s open and expansive farm and country lands. The music is always soft and flowing (like the clouds) and match the setting or feeling perfectly. There isn’t much heaviness to the soundtrack. The opening and ending themes fit the theme well and always as me listening to them as the credits and animations scroll by.


Overall it’s easy to enjoy this season. It’s deep enough that it doesn’t feel fake or cheap, but it isn’t so heavy that exhausts and bores either. It has steady and even pacing for an introduction of the later seasons (even if there was a lot of us that had to wait about a year between two and three each).


It is very easy to go straight into Zuko without and problems. The season ends at a good cut off point and leads very nicely into the next season. No confusion or too much recap.


I am writing this after the third time rewatching so there is another plus.


Only negative thing is Sasada Jun, I find her annoying and more annoying. She’s mostly for gags than anything else, but the season really could have done without her.


My score is 10 all the way; I’d rate it higher if I could. The start of my favorite series and the reason why I keep watching anime. Seriously everyone should give this a try.

I can't believe it took me so long to watch this. Initially I wasn't sure I would like it because the premise just didn't sound that appealing to me, but now that I finally got around to it, well, this is probably the first time I'm genuinely happy a slice-of-life series has a bajillion seasons.
Story 10/10: This is a very interesting show because, though it is certainly episodic, each episode presents an entire story, and that's what sets it apart from other such anime. The stories unfold slowly and the messages are subtle, but by the end of each episode I felt as though Ihad learnt something.


Art 9/10: The art is not incredibly polished, but it's colourful without being jarringly bright, and the backgrounds are drawn in a watercolour-y way, thus giving the entire show an aura of softness. The creatures we encounter are wonderfully diverse, ranging from cute to weird to sometimes creepy, which I really appreciated.


Sound 9/10: My only complaint about the sound is the voice acting, which was good but could have been better at times. Other than that, the soundtrack is absolutely beautiful, especially the ending theme. The background music is very peaceful and atmospheric, and, though not upbeat, it can be uplifting even when listened to outside of the anime.


Character 10/10: Natsume has become one of my favourite protagonists, because even in such a short amount he learns and grows, but he still has a long way to go. My favourite thing about him is how kind he is, especially towards the youkai, though they have inadvertently caused him a fair bit of suffering. He desperately longs for human connection, but at the same time finds it hard to open up to others, which is something a lot of us would find relatable. Other than him, there are a few recurring characters, and there are of course the creatures themselves, whose personalities and stories are just as diverse as their designs, and they are really what make the show as interesting as it is.


Enjoyment 9/10: There were some moments I found dull, though few, and I have to be in a particular mood to be able to watch this show. It's probably one of the least-bingeable shows I've come across, which might not necessarily be a bad thing, as I wouldn't really want to finish a season of it in an afternoon. Apart from that, it's certainly enjoyable, but not upbeat or comedic, more like peaceful or even melancholic. 


Overall 9/10: It would be very easy to give this a 10/10 but I am reserving that for its future seasons which I'm sure are even better. I do understand why this is one of, if not the, most popular 'healing' type anime, - I wholeheartedly agree with it, and honestly? I would absolutely recommend it to anyone, especially if you enjoy slow and atmospheric shows.

I'll tell you what, if you want a peaceful anime to partake in, this anime is the one for you. I always felt a tranquil feeling at the end of every episode.
So, if you're a fan of anime like Bleach or Noragami, I think this is something you'll enjoy. As I said, it's a lot more laid back than those anime, but it does give off the same vibe that they do. One thing I think you'll get a lot of through this anime is some really great stories. Natsume spends his days helping these youkai, and because of that, a lot of lovely storiesget told. That, I'd say, is what this anime is best at. 


Additionally, I love Natsume as a main character and how complexly he was written. You get to see a very compassionate character spread his kindness to everyone he can, and it's wonderful to watch.


The few, we'll say, "negatives" I have about this anime are simply that I wanted more expansion. Now, this seems like an issue that will be resolved in subsequent seasons, because this is an issue a lot of first seasons have. I want to see more about Natsume's background and upbringing to really get a sense for why he's so compassionate. Also, I'd like to see a continuous storyline crop up in the future because this season was, essentially, a new story for every episode. Lovely though they were, I'd like to see something a little more consistent.


Other than that, I think this anime is gonna be a great one for just about anyone. There's something fantastical about it, and yet, it comes with a serene calm. If you want to relax with something, please try out this anime, because I think it'll be just what you're looking for.

Natsume Yuujinchou is about a high school boy who can see Yokai, who inherits the "Book of Friends", basically a book for contracts with the Yokai. Accompanied by his cat-like friend, Mandara, otherwise known as Nyanko-sensei, as they return the names in the Book of Friends to the contracted Yokai.
To be honest, I was hesitant to watch the series at first, but it is an excellent watch and will definitely leave a great feeling when you finish the series! Be sure to watch the other three seasons too because they're awesome!
[Note: This review is for the WHOLE series. Also, this review has no spoilers!]
Now toget into the details...


STORY:

The story is unique in it's own way, I've never seen an anime quite like it and I don't know if I will be able to find one like it for along time. Some episodes will leave you tears because oh my gosh it's so sad sometimes. The story pulls you in and then keeps you itching for the next episode. It's gets really saddening though, as you watch episode after episode before reaching the end. You might even want to slow down so you'll have more time to savor such heartwarming storytelling. The limited romance and a good dose of action scenes, which makes it extremely enjoyable to those who want to step away from all the kissing and tsunderes for a moment.


CHARACTERS - 10/10

This is the first time I liked all the characters I came across. Unlike animes where I hate this one particular character, I found coming to the conclusion that I can't really hate anyone in this anime. Sure I may dislike some of the characters, but all the characters really grow on you. I would like to comment on how well the female characters are executed. There are no super tsunderes that get on your nerves or that super shy girl that is super clumsy. All the girls are relatively normal and I grew to like them, making it the first time I liked female characters as much as I loved the male characters. 


Natsume Takashi basically became my favorite during the few fist episodes. He's been through hell, but he just keeps trudging forward. The way he tries to avoid to cause inconvenience to the people around him is just so admirable, although I wish he would open up a bit more. I feel so sorry for him sometimes and I find myself shedding tears for him more than once. Nyanko-sensei is probably my favorite non-human favorite character too. 


It's hard to forget the characters you've seen, even the bad guys. Sometimes you're watching and you go "Hey, I wonder what this character is doing." Needless to say, you won't be forgetting about any of the characters here soon.


ANIMATION - 10/10

The animation is extremely good for it's day and age. Although rather plain looking to some people, it really has some gorgeous-simple scenes that make you want to wish that you lived there. I myself, would jump at the chance at living at such a peaceful town that Natsume is living in. 


Although some could compare this anime's animation to that of Sword Art Online, this anime was made in 2008 PEOPLE, 2008. It's pretty good if you ask me.


MUSIC - 10/10

Oh my gosh, the OST of this anime is so...beautiful. My favorite opening is from the second season (Zoku Natsume Yuujinchou), but my favorite song from this series is Ito wa Kanashi (OST Music). The music is fits right in with the action. Hearing some of the music makes you want to just sit on your porch and just watch nature to think about how fragile your life is. This is what the music is like. Also, everything is mostly traditional. There's no electronic tunes, most of the music is made by the traditional Japanese instruments, which gives this anime a very very peaceful feeling.


OVERALL JUDGEMENT - 10/10

Natsume Yuujinchou is probably one of the anime that I will never forget even though I tried. This is the first time an anime left me in such a peaceful state of mine. I had to take a moment after watching the last episode to just cry by myself. Yea, that's how the last episode of the series is like, just so peacefully happily sad. 


Nonetheless, Natsume Yuujinchou is probably became one of my most favorite anime. I haven't watched anything this good in a long long time. It's also like a breath of fresh air for those who are watching intense action scenes all the time. I highly recommend this anime to everyone! The series (including the other three seasons and 2 OVAs) is quite long too, so you don't worry about it being too short. I really hope that there's a fifth season, otherwise I would be rather saddened, but Season 4 has a pretty solid ending so I won't mind if it never did continue the anime. If not you can always read the Manga.


ANYWAYS IF YA HAVEN'T WATCHED IT, WATCH IT. IT'S REALLY REALLY GOOD.

Best show i have seen in a long time. Natsume Yuujinchou is thought-provoking, heart-warming, and emotional all in one. Every episode is fantastically made, giving viewers a wide variety of situations where they could place themselves in Natsume's shoes, not including the spirits of course. with many of these scenes there are moments that can be heart-breaking, sad, and can even bring a viewers who prepared themselves to let out a few tears, but what is so amazing about the anime is that it always finishes the episode with a warm ending, but not an ending that leaves viewers unsatisfied.
Story/Characters - 10
Given that it wasonly 13 episodes in length, the story progressed perfectly. But in some cases the order in which some episodes are watched doesn't really matter or affect the viewers understanding of the plot. in each episode natsume becomes involved with one or a group of spirits (Youkai as said in the anime). this encounter leads to a episodic adventure in which Natsume will help or solve that spirits problems. At a glance this sounds like a typical slice of life series, but what makes Natsume Yuujinchou stand out above the rest is the emotion that is put into each episode, friendship being one of them,  because it is a big part of Natsume's past which is a source of much of the emotion in the series.\n\n
Sound - 10\n
The opening and ending songs are perfect. Nothing more can be said about them except that they are a perfect match for this show and its themes.\n\n
Overall - 10\n
Definitely worth watching.

My rating for this is a 95/100 (for both seasons)
Ever since I saw a promotional image for this long ago, I looked forward to this series. I heard that it was going to be good, but I sure didn't imagine that a series like this was going to be THIS good! Yeah, the story's simple and has been done before. Boy sees demons, gets hated for it, fights them, etc. But this series  strays away from most of the stereotypes you see in those plots.
First off, let me start off by saying that this is the perfect summer series. All of the episodes arecalm, dreamy, and pleasant and leave you with a warm, fuzzy feeling inside. This series really does succeed at creating a perfect, dream-like atmosphere that the series emits. The pretty production values and adorable soundtrack contribute to that too. This series doesn't try to be super duper epic with a gabillion explosions or heavenly lights or anything of the sort. It simply does what it feels it has to do, and I feel they did it perfectly! For those of you looking for sparkly bishounen with rainbow-colored hair and big abs, this isn't the series for you. The character designs are perfectly normal and realistic (the only exception is that orange-haired girl) and don't try to be super duper beautiful, yet they do a great job with what they have!\n\n
And the characters! I haven't even begun talking about the characters yet! Everyone is neatly developed, even the youkai. Takashi Natsume proves that he's quite a strong character and is able to carry the series perfectly. Plus I can identify with him and his craving for acceptance and friends, since I myself have those problems too. He's had to suffer quite a deal in his childhood because of his ability, but he's learned from his mistakes from the past. Plus Nyanko is basically cracktastic in the best kind of ways! He's too hilarious to hate! Plus the series doesn't make the youkai seem like totally evil monsters who just like being evil. The youkai spend most of their time alone, and just one simple act of kindness, no matter how small, can mean the world to them. My personal favorite episode was the one with the little fox boy. He was soooo adorable and cute!\n\n
I guess the message that this series is trying to throw at us is that kindness, no matter how small or big, is never wasted and that there's value that comes from being in a group of friends, be it humans or youkai. This series captures this feeling perfectly. Everything is so dream-like and endearing, you would love to watch this series before bed. A wonderful series this is!

Natsume Yuujinchou turned out to be a rather simple, very human series at heart. The gentle simplicity to some of the tales, and each tale's lovely cast of characters, does a great job with creating a relaxing, slow-paced yet heartwarming series. The subtleties to a lot of the stories, and their endearing yet sometimes melancholic themes, tailors a rather lovable series that touches upon simple themes of life. While I was initially worried about was the very episodic nature of this series, it ended up that such worries were unfounded. Each 1-2 episode arc did an excellent job telling the story of Natsume as helooks to help out youkai in his own little way. The strength to this series would, almost definitely, be the characters, especially Natsume, Nyanko-sensei, and quite a few of the spirits(aka youkai) involved in the plot. There is a great sense of characterization amongst the cast, resulting in a fair number of enjoyable and well thought out characters. The pacing is a bit on the slow side, though, so don't expect any sort of hot-blooded, fast paced youkai action or anything of the sort.


The basic premise to the story is actually rather generic sounding, which originally rang off alarms in my head. Natsume, the main character, is a boy who was able to see youkai since his childhood. He inherits a book with the names of youkai written in it, and Natsume decides to return the names of the youkai to their respective owners.


While the story sounds typical, it's really the execution here that makes the series so endearing. The stories aren't very one-sided like one would expect, but rather, they are more balanced in perspective. It's easy to see how both Natsume (as a human) and the youkai (as spirits) both interact with each other and teach each other about the simple things in life. We learn about each of their respective hardships through their own perspectives, which adds some interesting insights to the main cast.


Each arc tends to have very retrospective, happy yet thought provoking endings, but at the same time this series doesn't hold back with it's melancholic, saddening arcs as well. This series touches upon simple themes in an unobtrusive, yet great way. It's amazing how powerful things such as a simple "thank you" or friendly "hello" could mean for some people, and this series does a great job at emphasizing such. This series may not always be very subtle about it's ideas, but it's certainly a series that you can easily relax to as you watch through it's endearing story arcs.


Artwork and music fit in almost perfectly with the general dream-like atmosphere to a lot of the series, adding gentle and pretty elements to the series as a whole. I can't say the music was exactly memorable, but it was very fitting for this series, and really contributed to the wonderful atmosphere this series had.


Notably, this series does have a rather slow pacing (similar to the famous Aria slice of life series), which means this is definitely not for people that can't stomach slow slice of life series. In a sense, Natsume Yuujinchou does require a bit of acquired taste, but that doesn't stop it from being a great series to just sit down and relax to. The atmospheric calmness to the setting, and the charms to the main cast, all add together in a wonderful little 13-episode package that certainly took me by surprise.

To me, this anime is like a warm cup of hot chocolate on a freezing cold day. True, it has it's suspenseful moments, but the kindness and warmth that can be felt through the story telling here is what really got me hooked. 
If I had to compare the feel of this anime to anything, it would be Kino no Tabi. However, some episodes of that anime left me feeling let down by the entire  human race. Natsume Yuujinchou and all of it's sequels have so far left either a smile on my face or a groove on my lip from biting too hardlol.


I can't decide if the best thing about this anime is the incredibly detailed, life-like characters, or the beautiful stories they tell. The art is simplistic in style, but I think it lends credence to the story telling. I'm not running out to get the theme/ending song, but I'm not fast-forwarding through it either. 


I have also read the manga, or, at least as much as I could find of it. If you can, read it and watch it. However, I have noticed that the anime has a few characters and stories that so far have not appeared in the manga. These additions flow seamlessly into the story and I would suggest watching the anime just for those extra stories. Aside from that, the only differences between the manga and anime is some differences in the order of stories, and that the anime has a soundtrack and the picture moves.


I cannot encourage people strongly enough to watch this anime. It's one of those beautiful treasures you don't find very often, quiet, unassuming but completely lovely. Before I found this anime, I had almost given up watching it entirely. Natsume Yuujinchou has re-kindled my love of anime.

At the beginning when I first began watching anime I couldn't bare to watch a single episodic show. The lonely boy who have problems making friends because of his ability to see youkais might sound like an old cliche for some but this anime crushed every thought about it. Natsume is a great made character who along with youkais and friends are made to truly fit the theme of this anime to bits. Its like a perfect puzzle with every piece. 


I cant tell how many times i have thought i need to rewatch it and how many times i have done exacly that. This anime is one of the greater ones out there atleast it was for someone like me. Times passed away as the anime pulled me into another world and i admit with my sheer enjoyment i have shed tears while watching this. There was never a moment i felt i didnt want to watch it. 


To the end this anime will be in my heart which i hope will be in many others. This is my first review. I'm writing a review about the whole season. I'm always confused that if he wants Natsume that is life will end. Some supporting characters actually serves a purpose on this show.  Enjoyment(9)                                                                                                             Overall (9)

I've started Mushishi right after finishing Natsume yûjinchô due to all the similarities and I notice that the latter is shoujo, the former seinen... they're distinct, yet parallel... while Natsume seeks out to grow and develop himself its 'masculine' counterpart seems to just serve as a caretaker, already wise...
Natsume is about feelings, essentially... he explores what might be, what was, what couldn't be... every episode can end in tragedy, but thanks to a deus ex machina in the form of a chubby cat... who is really this most ferocious wolf, things are reconciled. Not realistic, but at least Natsume himself is indeed vulnerable, especially whenalone... and loneliness seems to be a predominant subject in the series.


At times it can be sweet, others almost transcendental... visceral essentially, but also attempts to think things through; Natsume doesn't often act irrationally, although he seems to be perpetually optimistic.


This series, along with the aforementioned, may truly be the yin and yang of yōkai anime... and while the depths of the psyche can be perceived in both, Mushishi is generally darker... Natsume, being calmer, is not necessarily naïvely optimistic like, say, Aria can be... and generally has an episodic direction, and while there isn't much that is over-arching, there is ample time where all the ayakashi just decide to hang out...

Once you click the play button you will be hit with a wonderful opening which will draw you into the anime. Then towards the end of each episode, you'll be left with a nostalgic song; a beautiful piece of art. The highest quality of lyrics and singing will sooth your ears and submerge you in it's feelings.
Natsume Yuujinchou; a very simple anime which has done almost everything right. A boy who can see youkai (spirits) that no one else can. However, rather than your usual fighting anime, this anime focuses on the struggles and growth of the main character Natsume. How difficult must it be,to be able to see things no one else can and be called a liar for speaking the truth? Whether or not we choose to blame an entire species for our misfortunes is our own choice.


This anime is exceptionally good in my honest opinion, I myself am trying to refrain from finishing this series too quickly. As delighted as I was that there were a couple of sequels, I knew that they would be finished within the blink of an eye. Good anime's do that. They leave you always wanting more, wondering what's going to happen next. The anime is so heart warming and relaxing; it's a great break from the typical action or purely psychological sad anime.

Well, this is one series that gets you hooked from the first episode and gets better as you go on watching it! It's not flashy and neither does it particularly stand out. The most admirable things of the series are the simplicity of it's story and the detail. With a story like this one should overlook any superficial attributes like the picture quality or the sound (which are also excellent) but the message that we take from watching the show.
The character detailing was excellent in my opinion! We have a straight-forward protagonist in Natsume who has a heart of gold who goes around helping peoplewho are troubled (which is severely criticized by his "Sensei").  He has no "super-powers" per se, just a book that he inherits from his grandmother.


We see an orphan loner who's been through a lot in life finally finding his peace in a caring family and also see how Natsume understands his grandmother through the "Book of Friends". Each episode is a story arc of it's own. Natsume and the yokai teach each other a lot of things. About how co-existence between them is possible and how they are not so different. 


This show is a MUST WATCH.

This show is absolutely beautiful. The story is amazing and they somehow manage to fit a ton of drama into just one episode. 
It is mostly episodic like Mushi-shi and Hell Girl but the story is more that of XxxHolic. This is definetly one of my new favorite shows. 
The main character Natsume Takeshi is able to see spirits and inherited the "Book of Friends" from his grandmother. This book is filled with contracts, manifested as names, she made with spirits to basically be her servants. Some of the spirits just want their names back but others wish to steal the Book of friends fromhim so they can control those spirits with names inside. \n
Watch it, it's amazing!

Note: This is more a review of the entire series
The Nastume Yuujinchou series is a powerful and heartwarming fantasy masterpiece among the anime world. I absolutely loved the series and couldn't stop watching till the very end. The quality through all 4 seasons was just superb without a hint of drop-off. Once all the characters have been introduced (mostly in season 2), the show really takes off and we get a chance to really know everyone.
The range of emotions and themes covered in Nastume Yuujinchou is beyond impressive. It would have me ROFL with Nyanko-sensei's antics in one minute to within Clannad-esque tears in thevery next. However, what truly struck me was how N.Y. was able to find a duality/struggling conflict within all of these different themes and truly challenge the feelings and emotions of the viewer. This was done by creating such spectacular characters from Natsume and his family/friends down to the individual youkai that we meet for only a single episode. The creators do a magnificent job getting us emotionally invested in this world via these relatable and lovable characters.\n\n
It's an amazing ride (and I hope we get another season) as we join Natsume on his journey as he learns to accept and understand his ever changing world, the people/youkai around him, and, ultimately, himself. This is right at the top of my list of must watch anime. Don't think. Just watch.\n\n
Season 1: 8.5/10\n
Rest of the Seasons: 9/10

It feels like the anime itself is just one big piece of art work: in style, in meaning, and in heart.
This anime is like, a soothing balm to the heart (cheesy as though it may seem.)
The story is about a boy named Natsume, and every episode, he encounters youkai that have all these little stories and meanings behind them. 
The story is outstanding; it is beautiful in a simple way, and sometimes, that is the best way, especially in these chaotic lifestyles of ours these days. The music adds on to this peace; and sometimes you are so touched, you will start to cry. (Godknows how many times I did  while watching this series.)\n\n
The art is also very pleasing. The colors fit with the story and are soothing to the eyes. It enhances that aura of simplicity. \n\n
All in all, this is an anime you should definitely watch, especially when you're feeling overwhelmed in this hectic world of ours. Just... enjoy these little stories about the life of a boy who sees spirits.

Natsume yuujinchou is one of my favourite anime. The action and the adventure is not too heavy. The voice of Hiroshi Kamiya as Natsume is very calm and suits the character well. I totally fall in love with him and his personality.
 The characters aren't too many except for a few new youkai that were introduce in each episode. And speaking of the cute/funny Nyanko sensei! I wish I could have him. 
The story is easy to follow because it just mainly about the main character and the book of friend that consist of youkai's name. But you just have to bear with the sadpast experience of Natsume that is being told repeatedly. \n\n

this is my favorite anime.
I think the only reason why some people hate it is because it's literally a SOL (Slice of Life) meaning that it's kinda pointless and has no plot other than just following natsume's (the protagonist) life. The anime just gives you peeks into an odd boy's life and his development of personality. Sometimes, it's heartwarming; sometimes, it's sad. Either way, there's  no "goal." In action anime, the protagonist has to defeat an antagonist, in romance, the characters have to end up together (not always) but in slices of lives, it's basically just drifting around in an empty room. But otherthan that, let's get to the real review:


Story: When I first read the title a couple months back, I honestly thought it was going to be the most boring thing I'd ever seen, but it was summer and I had nothing to do, so I gave it a shot. Basically, Natsume was born with the power to see youkai (spirits) and he was ostracized for it. The whole anime tells of his development in personality as well as human AND youkai relationships. The first episode gave off a melancholic feeling. 


Art: When I first watched it, I was not impressed. I had just came here from really high graphic'd animes and I was expecting the same, but as I kept watching the series, the simple look grew on me. I can't imagine it any other way now.


Sound: I remember when I first watched it, I used to skip the OPs and EDs, but months later, they're all I listen to.


Character: All of the characters here will always have a place in my heart, 'nuff said. 


Enjoyment: As I said, I'm really biased and I personally loved it a lot. I rewatch it all the time. 10/10


Overall, I'd rate it a 9, only lacking in the art and animation (at first. The fifth season art is AMAZING)

I just finished watching this great anime. It was truly amazing. Although I heard about this anime a long time ago and knew it was on of the best animes out there, still I refrained from watching up until today. So, I finally realized what I missed out all this time.
When I was going through the top anime list I noticed this anime and Mushihishi at the same time. After reading their synopsis, I thought both were some kind of same. So I chose Mushihishi to begin with. But when I saw the first 8 episodes, I was kind of feeling down. The anime didnot meet my expectation. So, I thought Natsume would be something similar. But after watching it, I now realize that I was wrong.


Unlike Mushihishi, the story of Natsume felt like something that can be related to me and the people around myself. Because it focused on human relations more than Mushihishi.


How Natsume felt lonely during his childhood, how the people around him treated hime and yet he grew up to a person who did not hate humans, how his classmates treat him and tries to understand him, how his foster parents care so much about him, all seemed very warm and heart-soothing.


Story - 10/10


Unlike Mushihishi there was a story build up, you can't just watch any episode without watching the previous ones. And after watched one episode, you feel eager what's going to happen next - this is what I think the most strong point of a good story, and Natsume truly excels in it.


Art - 8/10


Natsu in japanese means Summer. The anime had such a beautiful, warm depiction of it, I enjoyed this very much. The art was simple but wonderful.


Sound - 10/10


Hell YES. This is the best part of the anime for me. After listening to ending theme, I was so struck by the Japanese folk singer Atari Kousuke that I became a fan of him instantly. Although I watched all the episode in one go, I never skipped the ending for all the 12 episodes, it was amazing. I liked it so much that I memorized it. I even went to listen other great songs of Atari - Hana, Sorezore ni. I am ready to give the sound 10, just for the ending song. The opening was great too. But the ending seems to fit the emotion and environment of the anime the best.


Character - 10/10


The characters are SUGOKU OMOSHIROI (very interesting).


Natsume, Reiko, Nyanko-Sensei, Tanuma, Touko-San, the Class President girl, Natori all were very very interesting.


Enjoyment - 10/10


I think I don't need to tell you how much I enjoyed this anime, I think my writing reflects it perfectly. Truly sensational. SUGEI!!!

This review only applies for the first 4 episodes of the series, it does not constitute for the overall experience of the anime itself and it will be comprised of what I liked/disliked about the anime and the reason I have had dropped it for.
Before I go on I'd like to let homeboy Natsume say a few things. Since he's quite lonely and all and he's a fictional character, he's not likely to speak his mind so I'm gonna give him a chance. So, Natsume, how do you feel right now?
"Being alone is lonely."
Oh, I'm so sorry to hear that. I'm curious what you're willingto do about it.


"I wanna do things I can do."


You're getting really philosophical Natsume. You're quite the poet. What else are you willing to share? Firetrucks are trucks on fire? The word word has 4 letters that form a word? Circles are circular round shapes known as circles in large circles of population? Despite their name, bulldogs are neither bull or dog? At least that's how it should be since pitbulls are neither pits or bulls.


I can't claim there's many more absurd quotes like the two I've quoted from the series in Natsume's Book of Absurd Quotes, but it is a good choice for you if you're looking for a series that showcases loneliness, solitude and isolation, which are Natsume's Book of Lonely Alone Beings most prevalent theme in the content I've watched.


Natsume's Book of People Doesn't Have A Plural And That's Why You'll Die Alone deals with a boy named Natsume who inherited his grandmother's book where she sealed the name of youkai which makes them subservient to her and he decided to give the names of these youkai back. In this process, Natsume's Book of Books Are Filled With Pages explores how Natsume and the Youkai felt isolated, were isolated and how being alone is lonely. It doesn't do a bad job in this process, actually it does do a decent job but my problem is that it withholds the same melancholic atmosphere in every episode and getting very sappy with it at times. It doesn't do a bad job presenting the feelings and circumstances through which these characters have gotten where they've gotten or a bad job in even presenting their feelings, but its overall atmosphere kills it for me. Every episode is the same with its melancholy tightly glued to it and having some generic anime humor  like oh that cat likes food hahaha oh it brought a frog, which is meant to relieve some of the tension, but since I don't share that type of humor, it does not work for me. Instead Natsume's Joke of Abstract Jokes amused me.


Natsume's Book of A Furry Can't Eat A Hotdog Because It'd Be Cannibalism doesn't resonate with me because most of its atmosphere is reserved and quiet which while it works for the show's theme, it feels too constant and while it does give the show a relaxing tone, it doesn't really play with my expectations in any sort of way, up to the point when a twist happens, I don't really care, because everything feels on the same constant all the time. But also the worst part for this show is that I'm on the exact opposite side of the feelings the show is trying to evoke. I personally value solitude a lot, I enjoy being alone and away from the public. I feel very relaxed by myself while I have nobody to interact with and value it each time. So the theme can't resonate with me even if I recognize what it does try to do and appreciate that, but if it doesn't put the events in a way I observe the experiences shown to me in a more direct way, I can't really empatize. It does present you enough, but it feels more like it's presented to be acknowledged rather than observed, which is what I usually seek from a series with an episodic focus on its events over the overarching plot.


Natsume's Book of Drawings Are Done By Drawing's artstyle is fine. It doesn't look impressive and fits the purpose of the show, best described as typical and traditional. Nothing wrong with that since you have a lighthearted show about youkai and isolation and I can't argue that it works. It won't impress you visually but it shouldn't bother you either.


As for Natsume's Book of Music Is Made With Sounds has a very relaxing and calming tone to it as a result of most of what you'll hear from the series is ambiance rather than music to deleniate the tone. Since it's set in a quiet rural area that's pretty much the result. The intro and the ending are some chilled out mellow songs that sound like classic japanese melancholy. Nothing noteworthy but definitely fitting.


Natsume's Book of I'm Funny And My Jokes Always Make Everyone Laugh seemed like a very chilled-out slice-of-life that is willing to explore the melancholy of a lonely child who's felt isolated due to being judged for the things he was perceiving. It isn't something that I have high odds of enjoying or am particularly looking for, since the reason I've decided to give this series a shot was the character development experienced by the characters in the series and there are meaningful messages to be carried, but what the central theme is and how it was meant to be executed is important, how the tone carries out and what type of lessons are to be drawn from it. And now you know. If you want to explore melancholy in a lighthearted fashion, give Natsume a try. If you don't, being alone is lonely and do things you can do. If you want. I don't expect it to change its tone or themes, especially in its first season. So if you're starting this series, this is what you should expect.

First off, let me say upon starting this series I had no doubt that it would have been beautiful considering the person who made Natsume  Yuujinchou also made Hotarubi No Mori e.
But my, was it so much more beautiful. It completely blew me away!
Story: 10/10
I'll warn you now, if you watch this you will most probably get emotional over every episode (At least I did). What's so amazing is that it constantly pulled out some emotion from me. Whether I was crying like a baby or smiling at the heartwarming moment, every episode was so emotional. 
The spiritual stories were so beautiful. I haven'tseen something like that in so long. I really wish there were more series like this out there, the stories of loss or heartbreak, love and joy. Each episode was like a roller-coaster of emotions!



Art: 10/10


The art was slightly different. And if you ask me, I really couldn't tell you how but I just noticed it was unique and fit the story line so well. Especially the opening title sequence was amazing. The art fit so well.


Sound: 10/10


The music, Oh my the music! I must have listening to the end and opening song more than 1000 times. It's not just that, the background music enhances the feeling and makes you want to cry even more. It seems very.. tradition? I don't know how to explain it well but all I know is that I didn't hear a single song in this show that I didn't absolutely love.


Characters: 10/10


It was a bit sad that most of the characters didn't stay to long, I think it was a bit disappointing that the show couldn't be longer. ( I know there is a second season that I have yet to watch) But it was beautiful (Yes, I must have used beautiful many times, but how else can I describe a show like this?) 


But all the spirits were so unique and I loved finding out about there stories even though it was sometimes sad.



Enjoyment: 10/10


I haven't seen the second season yet, but I hope I enjoy it as much as this one.



Overall. 10/10


Just perfect!

Natsume Yuujinchou is a series that seeks to convey the diverse emotions of the imaginary world of the yokai and ayakashi  and its connection with a high school student Natsume who happened to be lonesome dejected by the society because he is the only one who could see them.
The world of yokai is a place where there are various kinds of beings some malevolent and some mischievous , some bring good fortune and some are malicious, some who like humans and some are consumed by hatred towards humans. In every episode Natsume finds out how  these beings that have lead him to besecretive are not as bad as they are depicted, and in the process can make you cry sometimes.\n
With a new story every episode I have yet to see any other anime where just 20 mins are effectively used to make the story so sublime and characters so tender that sometimes it makes you cry. Its a feeling which any solitary person would find very restful and comforting. And I think each one of us has that little bit of solitude that would connect with it joyfully. Thats what make this series so unique and genuine. I strongly recommend this for all and see it when you are in nice space of mind to appreciate is thoroughly.\n
